name: Azure Virtual Network subnet is not configured with a Network Security Group
description:
This policy identifies Azure Virtual Network (VNet) subnets that are not associated with a Network Security Group (NSG). While binding an NSG to a network interface of a Virtual Machine (VM) enables fine-grained control to the VM, associating a NSG to a subnet enables better control over network traffic to all resources within a subnet. As a best practice, associate an NSG with a subnet so that you can protect your VMs on a subnet-level.

For more information,
https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/igorpag/2016/05/14/azure-network-security-groups-nsg-best-practices-and-lessons-learned/
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/private-link/private-endpoint-overview#limitations

Note: This policy will not report for subnets used by Azure Firewall, Gateway, NetApp File Share, Private endpoints and Private links as Azure recommends not to configure Network Security Group (NSG) for these services.
searchModel.query: config from cloud.resource where cloud.type = 'azure' AND api.name = 'azure-network-subnet-list' AND json.rule = networkSecurityGroupId does not exist and name is not member of ("GatewaySubnet", "AzureFirewallSubnet") and ['properties.delegations'][*].['properties.serviceName'] does not equal "Microsoft.Netapp/volumes" and ['properties.privateEndpointNetworkPolicies'] equals Enabled and ['properties.privateLinkServiceNetworkPolicies'] equals Enabled
recommendation:
1. Log in to the Azure Portal.
2. Select 'Virtual Networks', and select the virtual network you need to modify.
3. Select 'Subnets', and select the subnet you need to modify.
4. Select the Network security group (NSG) you want to associate with the subnet.
5. 'Save' your changes.
